awd_titl_txt: Debt as a Control Tactic in Marriage
awd_abstract_narration:
"Coerced debt" is an important but understudied form of intimate partner violence (IPV). It occurs when abusers in intimate relationships use fraud or coercion to generate debt in their partners' names. For example, abusers may fraudulently incur car loans in their partners' names or force them to make credit card purchases. Preliminary evidence suggests that coerced debt is a common problem with damaging effects on the lives of women with abusive partners. It can burden victims with hundreds or thousands of dollars in debt and damage their credit ratings, thus creating barriers to employment, housing, and utility services. These debts and barriers may be associated with long-term economic harm in large part because victims of coerced debt have difficulty attaining effective help from the two relevant legal systems: divorce law and debtor-creditor law. Despite these potential impacts of coerced debt, the research remains in its infancy. This project will be the first in-depth study of coerced debt. It will address fundamental questions about how coerced debt operates in abusive relationships, how victims seek and attain legal help for coerced debt, and coerced debt's effects on women's recovery from an abusive relationship.

This study will use a sequential mixed-method longitudinal design to collect data from a sample of women recently divorced from an abusive partner. The researchers will use public divorce records to recruit a sample of 180 women in Michigan and Texas (120 women with coerced debt and a comparison group of 60 without). The researchers will collect quantitative data through in-person interviews with the full sample. They will identify instances of coerced debt with an assessment tool used in conjunction with participants' credit reports as well as a tested methodology (life history calendar) to aid in the recall of focal experiences. The quantitative data will be used to investigate: 1) the types and amounts of coerced debt incurred in victims' names, tactics abuser use to incur it, and how victims learn of fraud; 2) differences between abusive relationships with and without coerced debt; 3) the extent to which help for coerced debt is available, accessible, and acceptable through divorce and debtor-creditor law; and 4) the extent of coerced debt's economic effects in the three months after an abusive relationship ends. Additionally, the researchers will conduct in-depth follow-up qualitative interviews with a subsample of up to 40 victims of coerced debt. The qualitative data will be used to gain a deeper, more nuanced understanding of how victims of coerced debt experience it in the broader context of abuse, facilitators of and barriers to attaining help through the divorce system, and the process by which coerced debt shapes victims' lives. In addition to publishing scholarship, the researchers will disseminate the findings to policy makers, service providers, and attorneys with the goal of ensuring that interventions to address coerced debt are evidence-based.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Coerced debt is a significant social problem about which very little was previously known. In the context of intimate partner violence (IPV), coerced debt occurs when an abusive partner uses fraud or coercion to incur debt in their partner's name. For example, abusive partners may fraudulently open credit cards in their partners' names or coerce their partners into opening vehicle or student loans. Abusers generate fraudulent transactions by incurring debt in victims' names without their knowledge. Fraudulent transactions in abusive intimate relationships are a form of coerced debt because abusers can conceal their actions or deter their partners from confronting them about the debt due to a fear of retaliatory abuse. In coercive transactions, the abuser demands that the victim incur debt, and the victim complies due to fear of harm if they resist, including physical violence, psychological injury, or economic retaliation. Some abusive partners also generate manipulated transactions by misleading or tricking their partner into incurring the debt. 

This first in-depth study of coerced debt aimed to provide: (1) a deeper understanding of coerced debt, including the types and amounts incurred and the tactics abusive partners used; (2) differences between abusive relationships with and without coerced debt; and (3) the extent to which the legal remedies for coerced debt are effective. Our research team interviewed 188 women recruited from divorce court records in a large county in a southern state. By design, approximately two-thirds of participants (116 women) had coerced debt, and a comparison group of 71 women did not (one participant was excluded because they did not meet the study criteria). Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, all research activities were virtual. We conducted telephone interviews to assess for coerced debt by systematically reviewing relevant accounts on participants' credit reports, asking about their ex-husbands' use of fraud, coercion, and manipulation (if no coercion) in creating these debts. We also asked about open accounts not on the credit report. Other data-collection activities included an online survey about demographic information and five types of abuse, a second telephone interview about the divorce process, and qualitative interviews with 37 participants via video call.  

Key findings include: 

  • Of 2833 participant credit accounts, 506 (17.9%) had coerced debt. 
  • Coercion was the most common tactic used to create coerced debt, with 380 (13.4%) accounts including a coercive transaction. Six percent (165) of the accounts had a fraudulent transaction, and 39 (1.4%) had a manipulative transaction. 
  • Almost half (48%) of all accounts in the study were credit card accounts, and 48% of all accounts with coerced debt were credit card accounts. Of participants with coerced debt, 49.7% had coerced debt on a credit card account.  
  • Coerced debt rates ranged from 16.1% to 29.2% for five of the most common account types in the study: personal loans (29.2%), mortgages (19.3%), student loans (19%), credit cards (18.5%), and vehicle loans (16.1%).  
  • Women who had children with someone other than their ex-husband and women whose ex-husbands perpetrated other forms of economic exploitation were significantly more likely to have coerced debt than their counterparts. 
  • Women with coerced debt had lower estimated credit scores compared to women without coerced debt. 
  • Divorce was an ineffective legal remedy. Of 99 participants with coerced debts that were active at the time of divorce, only 17 (17.2%) had any liability for their coerced debts transferred to their ex-husbands. Only one participant received money in the divorce to pay her coerced debts. When we added the total net liquid assets participants with coerced debt received in the divorce and subtracted them from each participant's total coerced debt, we found that participants had a median of $2,065.50 in coerced debt remaining. 
  • Because so few people use debtor-creditor law, we could not observe participant use of the three debtor-creditor laws we studied: (1) unauthorized use law, (2) the Texas statute of limitations, and (3) bankruptcy. Instead, as planned, we applied debtor-creditor law to participant coerced debts to determine probable legal outcomes and interviewed participants about their access to and willingness to use debtor-creditor laws. Based on these criteria, these legal rights were deemed effective for less than 10% of coerced debts. 

Developing Student Potential 

This project provided intensive training and practical experience for: one Ph.D. in Psychology, two Ph.D.s in Social Work, three M.S.W.s in Social Work (including one who was inspired by the project to enroll in an M.S.W. program), and more than two dozen law students. 

Broader Impacts 

To date, we have presented our findings to advocates, attorneys, bankruptcy professionals, and the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau as well as to five academic audiences. We are collaborating with two community projects that address coerced debt and are using a modified version of our study instrument to screen for coerced debt. We also developed two policy briefs that will help ensure that coerced-debt policy reform is evidence-based.
